name: 1912.06.0417 :: Calabash - Gourd Water Bottle

attributes.value: Large water bottle of gourd with burnt ornaments, wrapped with bast for easier carrying.

description: This large gourd water bottle, collected by Eric von Rosen during the Swedish Rhodesia-Congo Expedition of 1911-1912, is a remarkable artifact from the Bisa people of Zambia. The vessel's surface features burnt ornaments, a traditional decorative technique, and is wrapped with bast to facilitate carrying. This bottle exemplifies the ingenuity and artistry of the Bisa people in creating functional yet aesthetically pleasing objects for daily use.

collector_info.name: Eric von Rosen
collector_info.background: Eric von Rosen was a notable figure in early 20th-century exploration and ethnography. His contributions to the documentation of African cultures, including the Bisa people's way of life, have provided valuable insights into the diverse cultural heritage of Zambia. The collection and donation of artifacts like this gourd water bottle to museums have allowed for the preservation and study of African material culture.

event_info.description: The exhibition showcased the findings from the Swedish Rhodesia-Congo Expedition, highlighting the diverse cultures and artifacts collected by Eric von Rosen and his team. This gourd water bottle was among the many items presented, offering a glimpse into the daily life and craftsmanship of the Bisa people.

name: 1894.15.0035 :: Girdle/Belt with Cowrie Shells

attributes.value: Short leather strap girdle/belt adorned with sewn-on cowrie shells.

description: This girdle or belt, adorned with cowrie shells and dating back to 1894, is a testament to the craftsmanship and cultural heritage of the Mbunda people from Zambia. Collected by Emil Holub, a Czech explorer and ethnographer, during his extensive travels in Africa, this item represents the rich cultural exchanges between Africa and Europe in the late 19th century. Holub's contributions to ethnographic collections have provided invaluable insights into the material culture of Central and Southern African societies.

collector_info.name: Emil Holub
collector_info.background: Known for his travels across Africa, Holub contributed significantly to the understanding of African cultures. His work, including a notable expedition to the Zambezi and Congo rivers' sources, has left a lasting legacy in ethnographic studies.

event_info.event: Collection visit by Mulenga Kapwepwe and Samba Yonga
event_info.description: A visit aimed at studying Zambian artifacts within the framework of 'Empowering Women's Histories: Sharing Digital Heritage between Zambia and Sweden', highlighting the collaborative effort to make collections more accessible and relevant through digital means.

event_info.event: Collection visit by Victoria Phiri Chitungu
event_info.description: Part of the ongoing project 'Empowering Women's Histories', this visit focused on the examination and documentation of Zambian everyday objects, underlining the importance of preserving and sharing cultural heritage.
